title.abbrev: Performance and Liveness Monitoring in SR

front.title: Enhanced Performance Delay and Liveness Monitoring in Segment Routing Networks

abstract.t: Segment Routing (SR) leverages the source routing paradigm. SR is applicable to both Multiprotocol Label Switching (SR-MPLS) and IPv6 (SRv6) data planes. This document defines procedure for Enhanced Performance Delay and Liveness Monitoring (PDLM) in Segment Routing networks. The procedure defines the test packet formats similar to RFC 8762 (Simple Two-Way Active Measurement Protocol (STAMP)) and is applicable to end-to-end SR Paths including SR Policies for both SR-MPLS and SRv6 data planes.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Segment Routing (SR) leverages the source routing paradigm and greatly simplifies network operations for Software Defined Networks (SDNs). SR is applicable to both Multiprotocol Label Switching (SR-MPLS) and IPv6 (SRv6) data planes . SR Policies as defined in are used to steer traffic through a specific, user-defined paths using a stack of Segments. Built-in Performance Delay Measurement (DM) as well as Liveness Monitoring for Connectivity Verification (CV) and Continuity Check (CC) are essential requirements to provide Service Level Agreements (SLAs) in SR networks.

The Simple Two-way Active Measurement Protocol (STAMP) provides capabilities for the measurement of various performance metrics in IP networks . It eliminates the need for control protocol by using configuration and management model to provision and manage test sessions. The STAMP can be used for Performance Measurement (PM) in SR networks as well as liveness monitoring and connectivity loss detection of SR Paths. The STAMP test packets need to be punted from the forwarding path (to slow path or control plane) on the Session-Reflector and STAMP reply test packets need to be injected. This limits the scale for number of STAMP sessions and fault detection interval.

For Liveness Monitoring, Seamless Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (S-BFD) can be used in Segment Routing networks. However, S-BFD requires protocol support on the BFD-Reflector to process the S-BFD packets as packets need to be punted from the forwarding path and generate the reply packets thereby limiting the scale for number S-BFD sessions and fault detection interval. In addition, S-BFD protocol does not have the capability today to enable performance delay measurement in SR networks. Enabling multiple protocols in SR networks, S-BFD for liveness monitoring and STAMP for performance delay measurement increases the deployment and operational complexities in SR networks.

This document defines procedure for Enhanced Performance Delay and Liveness Monitoring (PDLM) in Segment Routing networks. The procedure defines the test packet formats similar to RFC 8762 (Simple Two-Way Active Measurement Protocol (STAMP)) and is applicable to end-to-end SR Paths including SR Policies for both SR-MPLS and SRv6 data planes.

section.title: Reference Topology
section.t: In the reference topology shown below, the Session-Sender R1 initiates a PDLM test packet and the Session-Reflector R3 transmits a PDLM return test packet. The PDLM return test packet is transmitted back to the Session-Sender R1 on the same path or a different path in the reverse direction.
The Session-Sender R1 and Session-Reflector R3 are connected via an SR path . The SR path may be an SR Policy on node R1 (called head-end) with destination to node R3 (called tail-end).

section.title: Loopback Mode
section.t: In loopback mode, the Session-Sender R1 initiates PDLM test packets and the Session-Reflector R3 forwards them just like data packets for the normal traffic back to the Session-Sender R1. The PDLM test packets are not punted at the Session-Reflector and does not process them and generate PDLM return test packets. The Session-Reflector must not drop the loopback PDLM test packets, for example, due to a local policy provisioned. No PDLM session is created on the Session-Reflector.

The Source and Destination IP addresses in the PDLM test packets are set to the Session-Reflector and the Session-Sender IP addresses, respectively (representing the reverse path). Both Source and Destination UDP ports in the PDLM test packets are allocated dynamically or user-configured from the range as specified in . The UDP ports used in loopback mode are different than the UDP ports used for STAMP test packets. The IPv4 Time To Live (TTL) and IPv6 Hop Limit (HL) are set to 255.

section.title: Loopback Mode Enabled with Network Programming Function
section.t: In loopback mode enabled with network programming function, both transmit (T1) and receive (T2) timestamps in data plane are collected by the PDLM test packets transmitted in loopback mode as shown in Figure 1. The network programming function optimizes the "operations of punt and inject the PDLM test packet" on the Session-Reflector as timestamping is implemented in hardware. This helps to achieve higher session scale and faster failure detection.

section.t: The Session-Sender adds transmit (T1) timestamp in the payload of the PDLM test packet and clears the receive (T2) timestamp. The Session-Reflector adds the receive timestamp in the payload of the received PDLM test packet in hardware without punting the packet to slow-path (or control-plane). The Session-Reflector only adds the receive timestamp if the source or destination IP address in the PDLM test packet matches the local node address to ensure that the PDLM test packet reaches the intended Session-Reflector and the receive timestamp is returned by the intended node. The payload of the PDLM test packet is not modified by any intermediate nodes.

The network programming function enables the Session-Reflector to add receive timestamp in the payload of the PDLM test packet at a specific offset which is locally provisioned consistently in the network. For example, for the PDLM test packet in unauthenticated mode defined in Figure 3, the 64-bit receive timestamp is added at byte-offset 16 from the start of the payload.

section.title: PDLM Test Packet Formats
section.t: The PDLM test packet formats for unauntheticated and authenticated modes are defined in this document as shown in Figure 3.
Sequence Number is the sequence number of the PDLM test packet according to its transmit order. It starts with zero and is incremented by one for each subsequent PDLM test packet.
SSID: PLDT Session Identifier.
Transmit Timestamp and Transmit Error Estimate are the Session-Sender's transmit timestamp and error estimate for the PDLM test packet, respectively.
Receive Timestamp and Receive Error Estimate are the Session-Reflector's receive timestamp and error estimate, respectively.

The timestamp and error estimate fields follow the definition and formats defined in Section 4.1.2 in [RFC8762]. Timestamp format preferred is 64-bit PTPv2 as specified in , implemented in hardware is desired.

section.title: Performance Delay and Liveness Monitoring
section.t: For performance delay and liveness monitoring of an end-to-end SR Path including SR Policy, PDLM test packets in loopback mode is used.

For SR Policy, the PDLM test packets are transmitted using the Segment List (SL) of the Candidate-path . When a Candidate-path has more than one Segment Lists, multiple PDLM test packets are sent, one using each Segment List. The PDLM return test packets are received by the Session-Sender via IP/UDP return path by default. The Segment List of the return SR path can be added in the PDLM test packet header to receive the return test packet on a specific path using the Binding SID or Segment List of the Reverse SR Policy .

section.title: PDLM Test Packets for SR-MPLS
section.t: The PDLM test packets are transmitted using the MPLS header containing the label stack of the SR Policy as shown in Figure 4. In case of IP/UDP return path, the MPLS header is removed by the Session-Reflector. The label stack can contain a reverse SR-MPLS path to receive the PDLM return test packet on a specific path. In this case, the MPLS header will not be removed by the Session-Reflector.

figure.title: Example PDLM Test Packet for SR-MPLS

section.title: PDLM Test Packet for SRv6
section.t: The PDLM test packets for SRv6 data plane are transmitted using the Segment Routing Header (SRH) containing the Segment List of the SR Policy as shown in Figure 5. In case of IP/UDP return path, the SRH is removed by the Session-Reflector. The Segment List can contain a reverse SRv6 path to receive the PDLM return test packet on a specific path. In this case, the SRH will not be removed by the Session-Reflector. When the PDLM return test packet contains an SRH at the Session-Sender, the procedure defined for upper-layer header processing for SRv6 SIDs in [I-D.ietf-spring-srv6-network-programming] is used to process the UDP header in the received PDLM test packets.

section.title: Enhanced Performance Delay and Liveness Monitoring
section.t: The enhanced performance delay and liveness monitoring of an end-to-end SR Path including SR Policy is defined using the PDLM test packets in loopback mode enabled with network programming function.

section.title: PDLM Test Packet with Timestamp Label for SR-MPLS
section.t: In this document, new Timestamp Label is defined for SR-MPLS data plane to enable network programming function for "timestamp, pop and forward" the received packet.

In the PDLM test packet for SR-MPLS, Timestamp Label is added in the MPLS header as shown in Figure 6, to collect "Receive Timestamp" field in the payload of the PDLM test packet. The label stack for the reverse SR-MPLS path can be added after the Timestamp Label to receive the PDLM return test packet on a specific path. When a Session-Reflector receives a packet with Timestamp Label, after timestamping the packet at a specific offset, the Session-Reflector pops the Timestamp Label and forwards the packet using the next label or IP header in the packet (just like the data packets for the normal traffic).

figure.title: Example PDLM Test Packet with Timestamp Label for SR-MPLS

section.title: Timestamp Labels Allocation
section.t: Timestamp Labels for unauthenticated and authenticated modes can be allocated using one of the following methods:

list.t: Labels (values TBA1 and TBA2) assigned by IANA from the "Extended Special-Purpose MPLS Values" . For Label (value TBA1), the timestamp offset is fixed at byte-offset 16 from the start of the payload for the unauthenticated mode, and Label (value TBA2) at byte-offset 32 from the start of the payload for the authenticated mode, both using timestamp format 64-bit PTPv2.

Labels allocated by a Controller from the global table of the Session-Reflector. The Controller provisions the label on both Session-Sender and Session-Reflector, as well as timestamp offset and timestamp format.
Labels allocated by the Session-Reflector. The signaling and IGP flooding extension for the label (including timestamp offset and timestamp format) are outside the scope of this document.

section.title: Node Capability for Timestamp Label
section.t: The Session-Sender needs to know if the Session-Reflector can process the Timestamp Label to avoid dropping PDLM test packets. The signaling extension for this capability exchange is outside the scope of this document.

section.title: PDLM Test Packet with Timestamp Endpoint Function for SRv6
section.t: In this document, Timestamp Endpoint function for "Timestamp and Forward (TSF)" (SRv6 Endpoint Behaviour value TBD2) is defined for Segment Routing Header (SRH) for SRv6 data plane to enable network programming function to "timestamp and forward" the received packet.

In the PDLM test packet for SRv6, End.TSF function is added for the target Segment Identifier (SID) in SRH as shown in Figure 7, to collect "Receive Timestamp" field in the payload of the PDLM test packet. The Segment List for the reverse path can be added after the target SID to receive the PDLM return test packet on a specific path. When a Session-Reflector receives a packet with End.TSF function for the target SID which is local, after timestamping the packet at a specific offset, the Session-Reflector forwards the packet using the next SID or IP header in the packet (just like the data packets for the normal traffic).

section.title: Timestamp Endpoint Function Assignment
section.t: Timestamp endpoint functions for "Timestamp and Forward" can be signaled using one of the following methods:

list.t: Timestamp endpoint functions (values TBA3 and TBA4) assigned by IANA from the "SRv6 Endpoint Behaviors Registry". For endpoint function (value TBA3), the timestamp offset is fixed at byte-offset 16 from the start of the payload for the unauthenticated mode, and endpoint function (value TBA4) at byte-offset 32 from the start of the payload for the authenticated mode, both using timestamp format 64-bit PTPv2.
Timestamp endpoint functions assigned by a Controller. The Controller provisions the value on both Session-Sender and Session-Reflector, as well as timestamp offset and timestamp format.

Timestamp endpoint functions assigned by the Session-Reflector. The signaling and IGP flooding extension for the endpoint function (including timestamp offset and timestamp format) are outside the scope of this document.

section.title: Node Capability for Timestamp Endpoint Function
section.t: The Session-Sender needs to know if the Session-Reflector can process the Timestamp Endpoint Function to enable the monitoring. The signaling extension for this capability exchange is outside the scope of this document.

section.title: Failure Notification
section.t: Liveness or connectivity success for SR Path is initially notified as soon as one or more PDLM return test packets are received at the Session-Sender.

Liveness or connectivity failure for SR Path is notified when consecutive N number of PDLM return test packets are not received at the Session-Sender, where N (Missed PDLM Test Packet Count) is locally provisioned value. The Sequence Number field in the PDLM test packets is used to detect the packets not received. Similarly, the delay metrics are notified, as an example, when consecutive M number of PDLM test packets have measured delay values exceed user-configured thresholds (absolute and percentage), where M is also locally provisioned value.

For the PDLM test packets generated by the Session-Sender R1 in the loopback mode, a failure on the reverse direction path can also cause the PDLM return test packets to not reach the Session-Sender. This is also true in case of the PDLM return test packets were generated by the Session-Reflector R3 e.g. to indicate Session-Sender R1 of any failure on the forward direction path. As such, the test packet based methods have this limitation for the liveness monitoring of the forward direction path.

In both loopback modes, the timestamps T1 and t4 are used to measure round-trip delay. In loopback mode enabled with network programming function, the timestamps T1 and T2 are used to measure one-way delay.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The Performance Delay and Liveness Monitoring is intended for deployment in the well-managed private and service provider networks. As such, it assumes that a node involved in a monitoring operation has previously verified the integrity of the path and the identity of the Session-Reflector node. If desired, attacks can be mitigated by performing basic validation and sanity checks, at the Session-Sender, of the timestamp fields in received PDLM packets. The minimal state associated with these protocols also limits the extent of disruption that can be caused by a corrupt or invalid packet to a single test cycle. Cryptographic measures may be used by the correct configuration of access-control lists and firewalls.
The security considerations specified in also apply to the procedures defined in this document.
